profile.profileDescription: Profile created on August 10 2022 at 19:43:30 by CollectiveAccess Administrator

label.description: 95 Montague Row, Box 1644 Digby Nova Scotia Admiral Digby Museum B0V 1AO (902) 245-6322 (902) 245-5196 admuseum@ns.sympatico.ca www.admuseum.ns.ca

label.name: Introduction
label.description: Narrative description for set. This is the primary text used when publicly presenting the set.

label.name: Item description
label.description: Narrative description for item in this set. This is the primary text used when publicly presenting the item in the context of this set.

label.name: Presentation type
label.description: Determines how set is rendered when displayed to the public in the Pawtucket/Pawtucket2 front-end.

label.name: Is primary item for set?
label.description: The item marked as primary will be used to represent the set as a whole when included in a list of sets.

label.name: Chronology element code
label.description: Element code of date range element to be used when placing set items into chronological order.

label.name: Authorization date
label.description: The date when the loan was authorized.

label.name: Loan in date
label.description: The date a loan will enter the institution.

label.name: Loan in date
label.description: The date a loan will enter the institution.

label.name: Loan return date
label.description: The date a loan is due back to the lending institution.

label.name: Loan renewal application date
label.description: The date to apply for a renewal to the loan.

label.name: Loan conditions
label.description: A statement of the conditions on a loan.

label.name: Loan note
label.description: General information about the loan.

label.name: Loan purpose
label.description: General information about the purpose of loan.

label.name: Movement method
label.description: The method used in the movement of an object.

label.name: Movement note
label.description: Additional information about the movement of an object or group of objects.

label.name: Planned removal date
label.description: The date an object is to be removed from its current location.

label.name: Planned removal date
label.description: The date an object was actually removed from its current location.

label.name: Reason for move
label.description: The purpose or reason for the movement of the object or group of objects.

label.name: Description
label.description: An account of the resource.

label.name: Caption
label.description: Short descriptive caption for item.

label.name: Notes (internal use only)
label.description: Notes regarding item

label.name: Date
label.description: Enter date or range of dates. Eg. 1950 - 1954; June 1982; 6/5/2010

label.name: Object nature
label.description: Nature of object (was object status in original Passage</i> database)

label.name: Check this box if you hold the copyright for this item
Description
label.description: Narrative biography for entity. This is the primary text used to document the entity.

label.name: Source of description
label.description: Source of entity biography. This should be a formal citation if possible. For informal sources a narrative description is acceptable.

label.name: Date founded
label.description: Date organization was founded.

label.name: Date incorporated
label.description: Date organization was incorporated.

label.name: Date of liquidation
label.description: Date organization was liquidated.

label.name: Brand names
label.description: Brand names under which the organization operated.

label.name: Made in Nova Scotia
label.description: Company that manufactured this artifact.

label.name: Georeference
label.description: Coordinates documenting the location of the item

label.name: Other Numbers
label.description: This field contains any alternative identifiers associated with the object.

label.name: Condition rating
label.description: Condition of item

label.name: Examination date
label.description: Date of condition examination

label.name: Condition documentation
label.description: Documentation of object condition

label.name: Date
label.description: Date of documentation media

label.name: Media
label.description: Image or document documenting object condition

label.name: Notes
label.description: Documentation media notes

label.name: Treatment date
label.description: Date of treatment

label.name: Treatment documentation
label.description: Documentation of object treatment

label.name: Date
label.description: Date of treatment media

label.name: Media
label.description: Image or document documenting object treatment

label.name: Notes
label.description: Documentation media notes

label.name: Treatment proposal date
label.description: Date of proposal

label.name: Treatment proposal documentation
label.description: Documentation of treatment proposal

label.name: Date
label.description: Date of proposal media

label.name: Media
label.description: Image or document documenting treatment proposal

label.name: Notes
label.description: Documentation media notes

settings.setting:
Enter the accession number; the unique record identifier for this item. The format should be the four digit year (YYYY), then the accession lot number, then the item number. For example, 2007.4.2

Do not enter colons, commas, semicolons or symbols as part of an Accession Number.

Do not use zeros as placeholders.

Do not include part numbers here, such as for a pair of shoes that have been given the designation of A & B. Parts should be outlined in the Description field, and the number of detachable pieces entered in the Number of Components field.

Enter the accession number; the unique record identifier for this item. The format should be the four digit year (YYYY), then the accession lot number, then the item number. For example, 2007.4.2

Do not enter colons, commas, semicolons or symbols as part of an Accession Number.

Do not use zeros as placeholders.

Do not include part numbers here, such as for a pair of shoes that have been given the designation of A & B. Parts should be outlined in the Description field, and the number of detachable pieces entered in the Number of Components field.

Enter the name of the object according to Nomenclature for Museum Cataloguing. The first letter of each word should be capitalized, for example Chair, Rocking instead of chair, rocking or CHAIR, ROCKING. Pick only one term from the range of terms (primary, secondary or tertiary) provided i.e. the term that is most appropriate and specific to the object. Uncertain data should be followed by a space and ?

Modifiers that help to distinguish this item from similar ones of the same name are cited in the Object Type and Object Sub-type fields. Classification terms, descriptive modifiers, qualities and attributes should not be entered here but should be included in other fields such as Description, Material, Colour, Culture, etc.

Research should be conducted on any unknown objects to determine their proper name, always focusing on the object’s original intended use. If the object term does not appear in Nomenclature follow the guidelines for adding object terms. If there is more than one name for the object, use the Alternative Name field to record other terms. Do not add qualifying data or extra details this field. The specific object type can be entered with more precision in the Object Type field (e.g. for a hospital bedside table, enter the term Table, Bedside in the Object Name field, and the term Hospital in the Object Type field).

Classifications to which the item belongs are cited in the Category and Group fields.
Names for objects must not exceed four words.
Name must not be more than four words in length
Object names must begin with an initial capital.

This field contains the descriptive modifier or secondary descriptor of the Object Name. Gender and age-based associations should be outlined here, such as Infant’s, Child’s, Woman’s, Man’s, or Doll’s. Multiple terms can be used by clicking Add Object Type to duplicate the field, ensuring that one qualifier is entered per field line. Attributed data should be followed by a space and ?

Do not duplicate the object name in this field.

This field contains the descriptive modifier or secondary descriptor of the Object Name. Gender and age-based associations should be outlined here, such as Infant’s, Child’s, Woman’s, Man’s, or Doll’s. Multiple terms can be used by clicking Add Object Type to duplicate the field, ensuring that one qualifier is entered per field line. Attributed data should be followed by a space and ?

Do not duplicate the object name in this field.
Object name must not be the same as object type
Object name must not be the same as object type
This field contains the secondary descriptive modifier of the object. Attributed data should be followed by a space and ?

This field is used to group items based on their original use and is a preset dropdown menu. Enter the sub-classification (3rd level category) as outlined in Nomenclature Museum Cataloguing. If an object had multiple uses and fits more than one sub-classification, the field can be duplicated and the appropriate information selected from the dropdown menu by clicking on Add Category.

Do not enter all three levels of Category, Classification and Sub-Classification. The dropdown menu is a hierarchy and the system understands which Category and Sub-Classification apply once the Sub-Classification has been selected.

Use this field to record the last legal owner prior to acquisition by the museum, i.e. the person who signed over legal title of the object to the museum. Contact information, birth & death dates, notes etc are entered onto the entity form according to the fields provided. For organizations, enter the name of the company or institution in the Source field and in the Cataloguer Remarks field note who signed for the gift on behalf of the company. For donations of jointly-owned property (i.e. siblings donating an object from their parents‚Äô estate), click the Add Source button to duplicate the field and enter each individual separately.

Use the dropdown menu to select how the museum acquired the item. In the event that paper documentation is lost, this is the museum‚Äôs proof of ownership of the object. Record ‚Äúpurchase‚Äù for any acquisition for which the museum gave money. Record ‚Äúgift‚Äù for any acquisition received without the museum giving payment (whether or not a tax receipt was issued). This includes bequests. Record ‚Äútransfer‚Äù for any acquisition received by the museum from another department within the museum‚Äôs governing society, corporation, or government body. Loans are not a method of acquisition.

Note: if paper documentation is lost, this becomes your proof of ownership.

This field displays on the Administration Page and Basic Page.

This is a dropdown menu that determines online access to the collection record. Choose ‚Äúaccessible to public‚Äù to approve online publishing, or ‚Äúnot accessible to public‚Äù to keep the record for internal use only. The default setting is ‚Äúnot accessible to public‚Äù.

Note: if any media files are attached to the record on the Media Page, their access level must also be set to accessible in order for them to be published online.

This field is for fine art and other objects that are titled, such as paintings, books, CDs, or records. Enter the preferred creator-given title for the object without quotation marks or additional punctuation. If the object has multiple titles, record the preferred title in Title, and then click on Add Title to duplicate the field and enter any additional titles. If there is important information in the title (e.g. information about the subject, materials, location, etc), also record that information in the appropriate fields. If the artist, writer, maker or designer did not assign a title, this field is left blank.

Do not use this field for household objects, tools, equipment, clothing, etc.

Do not use the term untitled unless the creator has deliberately named the work Untitled.

Provide a physical description of the object to create an accurate picture of it with words. Record only factual, objective information determined through careful observation. Where information is likely true but not confirmed, indicate accordingly or add a question mark. Where appropriate, use technical vocabulary to improve the accuracy of your description. At the same time, avoid terms that are so specialized they cannot be easily understood.

All information that is in the Description and is required for retrieval should also be indexed in appropriate fields elsewhere in the record.

Start with the object‚Äôs most obvious physical features to provide an overall picture of it to which the ‚Äòmental eye‚Äô can apply details. For example, describe the object‚Äôs shape with reference to the closest geometric form, or a commonly recognized form. Next describe physical characteristics which pertain to the object as a whole, such as the finish on wood, glaze on ceramics, or weave and pattern in textiles. Then describe the object‚Äôs distinguishing details in some kind of logical order, for example, beginning at the top and systematically working towards the bottom, or vice versa. If the object consists of composite materials include specific reference to the components to which they relate. Include specific dimensions of the object in your description only if you feel they provide important information, and they are not already recorded in the Dimension Remarks or Cataloguer‚Äôs Remarks fields. If the object has parts, be sure to include the letter or number designation for that part at the beginning of its description.

Do not use subjective language (i.e. old, big, fancy), abbreviations or slang.

Do not describe the condition of the object in this field. Instead record this information under Condition Remarks.

Do not record the details of any distinguishing text that appears on the object in this field. Instead, generally describe the nature of textual information and then transcribe this in the Marks/Labels field.

Enter a numeric date or date range to denote when the object was made. For archival documents such as diaries or ledgers, enter the date range for when the document was edited. If the year alone is not precise enough, record a more precise date, such as May 13, 1942. If a date is not known, determine a possible date range based on available information, such as 1900 to 1970. Qualifying terms can be used: Circa = approximate date, determined by researching other sources. Before = created before a certain date. ‚ÄúAfter‚Äù should not be used as a qualifier since it is known the object was made prior to entering the museum, allowing a date range to be applied.

Describe the original and subsequent use(s) of an object, in chronological order, and using paragraph form. General information that explains the item‚Äôs role in the evolution of science and technology, and/or its significance to the community, should be entered here. Specific information about the people, experiences, and life history of the item should be entered in the Narrative field. All information that is in the History of Use field and is required for retrieval should also be indexed in appropriate fields elsewhere in the record.

Include any references in the Catalogue Reference field and any hyperlinks on the Web Links page.

Do not include private information, such as the name of the donor.

Do not use abbreviations or slang unless you explain their meaning.

Enter the object‚Äôs major materials in order from most predominant to least predominant, separated by a semicolon and space. Use lowercase except where the material is distinguished by a proper noun, such as Carrara marble, or is known by its brand name, such as FormicaTM. When applicable, include both general and specific terms for a material, separated by a comma, i.e. wood, pine or metal, copper. If the specific material is unknown, enter the general material, such as wood. Uncertain data should be followed by a space and ?

Do not use abbreviations or slang.

Enter the greatest overall metric dimensions of the object using the applicable fields. Enter the numerical value with the appropriate metric unit, i.e. 20.3 cm. For objects with parts, record the overall dimensions of the object assembled. Measurements for significant parts (important for research or storage purposes) should be recorded under Dimension Remarks and specifically identified with the part number, for example: The print (part A) was measured without being removed from the frame (part B).

Do not measure the object using the Imperial system (inches).

Enter the number of identical items included in the catalogue record. For example, rather than entering 6 individual records for a set of dishes, create one record for the set and enter the number 6 in this field.

Enter the number of detachable pieces or parts that make up the object described in this record. Generally, a component is a removable or separate part that is integral to the object and cannot be used for its intended purpose without the other part(s). For example, a sugar bowl with a lid has two components.

This field indicates the building, room, and unit where the item is permanently located or stored. Storage Locations are preset in the database as a hierarchy. By typing in the name of the most specific location, i.e. Drawer 3, the system will generate suggestions from which you can select the appropriate location.

Select the term from the drop down list which best describes the overall condition of the object at the time of acquisition.

Excellent ‚Äì no damage/deterioration

Very Good ‚Äì normal signs of wear

Good ‚Äì slight damage/deterioration, dirty

Fair ‚Äì problems more severe, handling and exhibit concerns

Poor ‚Äì unstable, difficult handling, needs attention

Very Poor ‚Äì severe deterioration, should not be handled or used for exhibits

Use this field to describe the object‚Äôs condition, outlining location and extent of damage, deterioration and/or wear. For example: Photograph is torn in lower right corner. If the object requires specific handling instructions related to its condition, record them here.

Do not repeat the general condition term
This field denotes the level of completeness of the record. Select from the dropdown menu to tag items that are undergoing editing, require review, or have been completed.
Authority list connected to the NS Industries Database.

This field indicates the processes, methods or techniques used to manufacture the item. The term(s) should be entered in lower case except when a proper noun is part of the term. Use the past tense; ie carved, cast, sculpted, or sewn. For objects which were created by multiple techniques, click on Add Manufacturing Technique to duplicate the field, and enter each technique on its own line. Complex modern items mass-produced in factories can simply be referred to as manufactured.

Any and all people, organizations, and/or companies associated with the item should be added here. Each entity should have its own entry line. If multiple names need to be added, click the Add Relationship button to duplicate the field and enter each individual separately. This field draws from the entity list in the database, so once you begin typing a name the system will generate suggestions from which to choose. Click on the correct name, and then choose the person/organization‚Äôs role from the drop down list. Options include author, collector, conservator, creator, examiner, manufacturer, merchant, original owner, and source.

Note: This field also displays on the Relationships Page.
Provide details about the form and location of the artist‚Äôs or maker‚Äôs signature as it appears on the object, i.e. Written in black ink in lower right corner: T.A. Stone.

Use this field to record details about this specific object‚Äôs history, including its use, the history of the owner, business, events, etc. that relate to the object. Enter the information in chronological order. Try to avoid including ‚Äúgeneral history‚Äù, for example the record of a rifle used at the Battle of the Somme should have noted that it was used in that battle, but general history of the battle itself or WWI is unnecessary. All information that is in the Narrative and is required for retrieval should also be indexed in appropriate fields elsewhere in the record.

Include any references in the Catalogue Reference field and any hyperlinks on the Web Links page.

Do not include private information, such as the name of the donor.

Do not use abbreviations or slang unless you explain their meaning.

Enter the distinguishing colours that will help to identify the object, in order of most predominant to least predominant, and separating multiple entries by a semi-colon and space. For example: Blue; Yellow; Green

Do not include information about which parts of the object are which colour.

Note the location and method of all markings and/or labels on the object, such as manufacturer stamps and symbols, clothing labels, etc. Outline how the marking was made, ie stamped, engraved, written, and transcribe the information. Line breaks can be expressed by a forward slash. For example, Oval paper label on the bottom of the chair states: Made by J.W. Stanley / Digby.

Do not transcribe long sections of text such as the description on the back cover of a book.

Do not use quotation marks unless they are on the mark/label.

This field identifies the culture associated with the object based on its social/geographic origin. Enter the name of the culture, capitalizing the first letter and using the adjectival form, ie Acadian, Mi‚Äôkmaq, Scottish, etc. Multiple cultures should be entered separately, using the Add Culture button to duplicate the field. Uncertain data should be followed by a space and ?

Do not include any other explanatory information in this field.

Enter the full name of the battalion, regiment, company, squadron, etc. that is specifically associated with the object. For example, 435 Transport and Rescue Squadron or The Halifax Rifles. If multiple units are connected to the item, click on Add Military Unit to duplicate the field, entering each unit on its own line. Attributed data should be followed by a space and ?

Do not use abbreviations, acronyms or slang terms.

Enter the full name of the vessel(s) associated with the object, formatting as follows: ship name, type abbreviation. For example: Sackville, HMCS. If more than one vessel is connected to the item, click on Add Vessel Name to duplicate the field. Each vessel should be entered on its own field line. Attributed data should be followed by a space and ?

This field can be used to connect associated items in ways not covered by the Category field or Relationships Page. Political parties, fraternities or other organizations, sports, etc., are examples of grouping options. Attributed data should be followed by a space and ?

Enter the brand name of the manufactured product, such as Cheerios. For multiple brand names, click Add Brand to duplicate the field and enter each on its own line. Attributed data should be followed by a space and ?

This field contains the manufacturer‚Äôs model name and/or number for the object, for example model 612b. Multiple entries can be added by clicking on Add Model to duplicate the field. Each different model name or number should be entered on its own line. Attributed data should be followed by a space and ?

This field contains the unique serial number assigned to the object by the maker. Enter the number as it appears on the item, for example sn123456. If there are multiple serial numbers, click on Add Serial Number to duplicate the field and enter each number on its own line.

Enter all patent/copyright dates and/or numbers as they appear on the object, such as Patent no.651234. Multiple entries can be added by clicking on Add Patent Date and/or Number to duplicate the field. Different dates or numbers should be entered on their own line.

This field contains the name of a person or business that contributed to the creation of the item but is not mentioned in the Related Entities field. For instance, a portrait artist would be listed as the Creator, but the person who framed the painting could be listed here. Enter information in the following format: Last Name, First Name. For businesses, enter the name in natural order. If multiple technicians need to be listed, click Add Technician to duplicate the field, and add each entry on its own line.
This field outlines the role of the technician who contributed to the creation of the object. For instance, if the technician listed framed a painting, Framer would be entered here.

This field contains the name of the publisher of the book, portfolio, or series that incorporates the object. Enter the name of the publishing company in natural order, such as LB Smith & Sons. If multiple publishers need to be listed, click Add Series Information to duplicate the series fields, and add each entry on its own line.
This field contains the title of the book, portfolio, or series that incorporates the object. Enter the title as it appears on the item.
This field contains date of publication for the item. Enter the most specific date possible. If there were multiple printings or publication dates, enter the most recent date listed on the item.

Use the dropdown menu to select how the museum acquired the item. In the event that paper documentation is lost, this is the museum‚Äôs proof of ownership of the object. Record ‚Äúpurchase‚Äù for any acquisition for which the museum gave money. Record ‚Äúgift‚Äù for any acquisition received without the museum giving payment (whether or not a tax receipt was issued). This includes bequests. Record ‚Äútransfer‚Äù for any acquisition received by the museum from another department within the museum‚Äôs governing society, corporation, or government body. Loans are not a method of acquisition.

Note: if paper documentation is lost, this becomes your proof of ownership.

This field displays on the Administration Page and Basic Page.

Enter the date that the museum obtained the item. The date format should be Month Day Year, for example April 12 1949. If the day and/or month are not known, enter the month and year, or just the year. In the case of very early acquisitions, if no date is known leave this field blank.

Note: if paper documentation is lost, this becomes your proof of ownership.

Enter the date that the museum formally accepted legal ownership of the object, i.e. the date the donor signed the Gift Agreement form, or the date of sale, etc. The date format should be Month Day Year, for example April 12 1949. If the day and/or month are not known, enter the month and year, or just the year. In the case of very early accessions, if no date is known leave this field blank.

Note: if paper documentation is lost, this becomes your proof of ownership.
This field indicates the status of the item, i.e. whether it is an original, copy, replica, reproduction, or of unknown nature. Choose the appropriate term from the dropdown list.

This field contains the code or reference number assigned to prints, negatives or slides related to the item. For instance, if a professional photographer wrote ColeHbr 1943-1 as a reference number on the edge of a slide, document this number here. If there are multiple codes, click Add Photo Number to duplicate the field, and add each code on its own line.

Do not enter the file names of images that are attached to the collection record.

User this field to record the name of the individual responsible for completing the initial catalogue worksheet for this item. Enter names in the following format: Last Name, First Name. For example: Ring, Dorothy. If more than one person catalogued the item, separate multiple entries by a semi-colon and space.

Do not change this name when an adjustment is made to the record.

This field indicates the date on which the initial catalogue worksheet was completed for the item. Enter the date in the following format: Month Day Year.

Do not change this date when an adjustment is made to the record.

Use this field to record miscellaneous administrative notes about the item, i.e. important information pertaining to the object but that should not necessarily be made public. This can include remarks about the acquisition process, inventories conducted, research required, etc. For example: Object found in collection during 1987 inventory.

Use this field to record any references used during the cataloguing process, whether they are books or interviews with experts. Enter the references in a technical citation style, generally in the format of: Author last name, first name, Year. Title of article, journal or book. Editor, Publisher, City. Pages. If multiple references need to be listed, click Add Catalogue Reference to duplicate the field, and add each entry on its own line.

Do not enter website links here. They should be entered on the Web Links page.

This field is a holdover from the old Passage collections management database, providing links to similar or related items in the collection. Information in this field should be moved to the appropriate field on the Relationships Page. The field will then be deleted from the system.

This field contains the history of exhibitions in which the item was included. Enter the full name of the exhibit followed by the date or range of dates that the exhibit was on display. For example: From the Cradle to the Grave Exhibit, Summer 2009. If the item has been used in multiple exhibits, click Add Exhibit History to duplicate the field, and add each entry on its own line. Multiple entries should be listed in chronological order.

This field gives details of restrictions on the item and/or record. These can be related to the condition requirements, such as keeping an object away from bright lights or heat sources. They could also be related to security issues, such as removing an object from display and locking it in a safe overnight. For archival holdings, restrictions are often based on the information contained in a document or file, i.e. public access may not be granted until a certain year or until after the donor is deceased, or a photograph may not be copied without the permission of the copyright holder.
Enter the date that the item was formally removed from the collection. Format should be Month Day Year.

Select the method of disposition from the dropdown list. Options include: Destroyed (for items damaged beyond repair), Exchanged (given to another museum or institution), Repatriated (returned to the rightful owner), Sold, Stolen, Transferred (moved to another department of the museum, such as to the working collection), and Unknown (for early deaccessions lacking documentation).

This field contains a brief justification for why the item was removed from the collection. For example: The bowl was dropped and broken beyond repair on September 3, 1997, or The photo album was sent to ABC Archives as it did not fit our collections mandate.

Note: Full documentation should be completed using the Deaccession Proposal and Deaccession Worksheet. These must be completed for each item being removed, and these documents kept in the object‚Äôs file.

This page is for adding any image, audio, video, document, and/or multimedia files associated with the object. File names must match the accession number, replacing the dots with dashes or underscores. For example, the photograph of a chair numbered 1990.3.5 would be saved as 1990_3_5.jpg. To attach more than one media file, click Add Representation to duplicate the field. Additional views or media files follow this same format with a qualifying term at the end, such as 1990_3_5_side.jpg or 1990_3_5_label.jpg.
Indicates the type of media representation. The type can only be set when attaching a new media file, and cannot be changed once the record is saved.

This field denotes the level of completeness of the media representations for this item. Select from the dropdown menu to tag media files that are undergoing editing, require review, or have been completed.
When multiple media files are attached, use this dropdown to select which is the primary image, i.e. which image you want to display during search results and the record thumbnail.

This is a dropdown menu that determines online access to the media files attached to the record. Choose ‚Äúaccessible to public‚Äù to approve online publishing, or ‚Äúnot accessible to public‚Äù to keep the media files for internal use only. The default setting is ‚Äúnot accessible to public‚Äù.

Note: if the item is set to not accessible on the Basic Page, the media files will not be published online even if they are set to be accessible to the public.

Enter the date that the condition report was completed on this item. When additional examinations are made, click Add Examination Date to duplicate the field, adding each date on its own line in chronological order. Dates should be formatted as Month Day Year.

Enter the name of the individual responsible for completing the condition report for this item. If multiple people were involved, click Add Examiner to duplicate the field, entering each person on their own line.

Note: This field is linked to the Related Entities field.

Enter the name of the professional conservator who worked on the object, conducting repairs or stabilizing the item. If conservation work was done by different conservators, click Add Conservator to duplicate the field, adding each conservator on their own line.

Note: This field is linked to the Related Entities field.

This field indicates how the item has been stored or housed in the museum. If the item is stored differently than it is displayed, outline each method. For example: When in storage the dress is kept on a padded hanger on the textile storage rack, which is covered with cotton sheeting. On display a 19th century mannequin form is used.

Do not enter the formal storage location in this field as it is already entered elsewhere.

This field contains remarks about any conservation, preservation or treatment not covered in other fields. This may include recommendations from the conservator on care and handling of the item, frequency and methods of environmental monitoring, etc. It can also include notes on how the item was treated in the past, such as the donor having made a repair to a vase with crazy glue. If multiple condition reports have been completed and different conservators left notes, click Add Conservation Notes to duplicate the field and enter each note on its own line, being sure to mention the date & author of the notes.

Enter the dates when conservation treatment was completed on the item. If multiple treatments were conducted, click Add Treatments to duplicate the field, entering each treatment on its own line. Formatting should be Month Day Year.

This field outlines any additions made to the original item over the course of its history. List the materials, methods, and locations of all additions. For example: Muslin backing attached by blanket stitch to support the sampler and help maintain its shape.

This field outlines any work done on an object over the course of its history in order to counteract damage or deterioration. List the materials, methods, and locations of all repairs. For example: Teacup handle was reattached using 5% Paraloid B72 in Acetone.

This field outlines any coatings applied to the object over the course of its history. These may affect care and handling, storage, and/or conservation treatment methods or requirements. For example: Tannic acid was applied to the blade.

Enter any name variations for the item, such as local slang terms, colloquialisms, alternate spellings, etc. If multiple alternatives exist, click Add Name to duplicate the field and enter one on its own line. Attributed or uncertain alternate names should be followed by a space and ?

Use this field to link other objects in the collection that are similar or are in some way connected. The field is a lookup, and searches can be done by Accession Number or Object Name. If multiple items need to be linked, click on Add Relationship to duplicate the field. Each item must be entered on its own line, and the relationship type selected from the dropdown menu ‚Äì is version of, references, has version, is referenced by, or is related to.

Do not link all items connected to an individual as the system links these through the Related Entities field.

Any and all people, organizations, and/or companies associated with the item should be added here. This field draws from the entity list in the database, so once you begin typing a name the system will generate suggestions from which to choose. Click on the correct name, and then choose the person/organization‚Äôs role from the drop down list. Options include author, collector, conservator, creator, examiner, manufacturer, merchant, original owner, and source. If multiple names need to be added, click the Add Relationship button to duplicate the field and enter each individual separately.

Note: This field also displays on the Enriched Page.

This field lists any historical events to which the item was connected. The event may be local in scope, such as a church picnic, or broader and well known, such as the Battle of Vimy Ridge. This field draws from the historical events list in the database, so once you begin typing a name the system will generate suggestions from which to choose. If multiple events need to be added, click the Add Relationship button to duplicate the field and enter each individual separately.

This field is for tagging the item as being part of a large-scale collection, such as coming from a heritage institution that closed. This field draws from the collections list in the database, so once you begin typing a name the system will generate suggestions from which to choose. If multiple collections need to be added, click the Add Relationship button to duplicate the field and enter each individual separately.

Do not use this field to create collections for every donor.

This field draws from the loans list in the database, so once you begin typing a loan number or object name the system will generate suggestions from which to choose. If no loan record has been created, go to New ‚Äì Loan, and create a record for that item. The item can then be linked as being part of the loan.

Map any locations related to the object, such as where a photograph was taken or where an object was made. Pinpoint a location by typing the place name in the search bar. Hit enter or click the magnifying glass icon and the map will reposition to the location and insert a dot. For street level locations, zoom in to make sure the dot was put in the right spot. If necessary, move the dot by clicking and dragging it to the correct location. You can also map an area, such as an archaeological site, property boundaries, etc. To do this, search for your location and then select one of the outline tools. Click to create boundary points and draw the desired area. Double-click to stop drawing, and save the record.
Enter the website address of any relevant online resources connected to this item, or that provide contextual information on the item‚Äôs history.

Provide a brief description about the website url listed above, explaining what information it contains and/or why someone should look at the site. Include the date that the website was accessed. If more than one online resource needs to be added, click Add External Link to duplicate the fields, entering each on its own line.

Enter the title of the fonds to which the item belongs. The fonds consists of all of a creator’s documents (on paper and other formats) written and/or accumulated and used by a particular individual, business or organization in the course of that person’s life or that business’s activities or functions. The general rule is to use the name of the creator of the files followed by the word fonds, such as Lillian Stanley fonds.

Do not capitalize the word “fonds”.

Enter the title of the fonds to which the item belongs. The fonds consists of all of a creator’s documents (on paper and other formats) written and/or accumulated and used by a particular individual, business or organization in the course of that person’s life or that business’s activities or functions. The general rule is to use the name of the creator of the files followed by the word fonds, such as Lillian Stanley fonds.

Do not capitalize the word “fonds”.
Do not use the redundant word "fonds" in fonds titles.
Fonds title must not contain the word "Fonds"

This field describes a group of records within a fonds that are arranged or maintained as a unit because they relate to a particular function or subject, result from the same activity, have a particular form, or owing to some other relationship arising out of their creation or arising from their receipt and use. The series field is used when creating multilevel descriptions ‚Äì first provide information about the fonds as a whole, then increase the specificity by providing information relevant to the aggregate groupings.
This field is not commonly used, but may be used to further specify groupings within a series. Use the rules for describing a series to describe a sub-series.

This field describes an organized unit of documents, usually within a series, brought together because they relate to the same subject, activity, or transaction. Remember that a file is not necessarily just one physical file folder ‚Äì it is an organized unit of documents relating to a particular activity or subject and may be made up of a number of folders or group of sound recordings, photographs, video cassettes, or other kinds of material.

This field briefly describes any publicly accessible research aids created for this item. Include the date of creation of the finding aid, if known. For example: Copy of newspaper clipping placed in reference file under Community Histories.

This field indicates how many people owned the document before it came to the museum. Give the names of the people/businesses and the dates they owned or had custody of the item, if known. For example: the photograph album was found in the attic of a house on Ridge Road in Wolfville. The home was originally owned by George and Elzina Cook in the 1890s. Their grandson found it and donated it to the historical society in 1964.

This field contains text to describe the document, and is used to provide descriptive information that is not in other fields. Give the subject matter and data it records, and the geographical area to which its contents pertain. If the document is a copy or transcript, give the date the copy was made, the method used to create the copy, and where the original is kept, if known. For example: Item is an alphabetical listing of qualified electors for Queens County, Nova Scotia, for 1893 election.

This field is used to provide information that does not fit into any other area of the description, to clarify or explain information, or to provide additional descriptive information about the unit being described. Examples of information to include may be the source of the supplied title, restrictions on access, physical condition of the material, dates of accumulation, and conservation treatment.

This field is used to provide information that does not fit into any other area of the description, to clarify or explain information, or to provide additional descriptive information about the unit being described. Examples of information to include may be the source of the supplied title, restrictions on access, physical condition of the material, dates of accumulation, and conservation treatment.
For archival maps and architectural plans, use this field to indicate the scale of the drawing or map. Enter the scale as a representative fraction expressed as a ratio, for example 1:100.
For archival maps and architectural plans, use this field to indicate the scale of the drawing or map. Enter the scale as a representative fraction expressed as a ratio, for example 1:100.
Map scale ratios must be proper ratios.
Map scale ratios must be in the format #:# (Eg. 1000:1)

For artifacts, this field contains keywords or terms that refer to iconographic content of the object, such as in paintings, photographs or postcards. For archival records, this field contains terms which briefly describe the main topic of the item, such as streetscape, farming, etc. The recommended standard list is the Nova Scotia Subject Headings Authority. Multiple subjects can be assigned by clicking Add Subject to duplicate the field; each subject term being entered on its own line. Attributed data should be followed by a space and ?
You must set the access setting to "public" for images to appear on NovaMuse.
You must set the access setting to "public" for these images to appear on NovaMuse.
You must set the access setting to "public" for these images to appear on NovaMuse.
Width of representation should be at least 800 pixels
Width of representation should be at least 800 pixels
Height of representation should be at least 800 pixels
Height of representation should be at least 800 pixels
Don't forget to set georeference type
Don't forget to set georeference type

role.name: Administrators
role.description: Confers actions needed by those administering the system

role.name: Cataloguers
role.description: Confers actions needed by those editing catalogue entries

role.name: Researcher
role.description: Allows users to only search and view - but not edit - catalogue entries

role.name: User content moderator
role.description: Allows users to moderate user generated tags and comments

group.name: Cataloguers
group.description: Users who can add and edit catalogue entries
